etymology.description: 豆(bean) + 瓣(segment/split) + 酱(sauce/paste) = paste made from split beans (often broad beans), typically with chili.
etymology.interpretation: Literally “bean-segment sauce,” referring to a thick fermented paste made from split broad beans; in Sichuan cuisine it commonly includes chili, hence ‘chili bean paste’.
etymology.simplification: Only 醬 was simplified to 酱, replacing the complex phonetic 將 with 将 under the 酉 ‘fermentation/wine’ radical to reduce strokes and ease writing; 豆 and 瓣 are unchanged.

parts.english: bean; legumes; ancient food vessel; small bean-shaped thing
sauce; paste; thick soy/bean paste; condiment

examples.chinese: 这道鱼香肉丝要用一勺豆瓣酱(這道魚香肉絲要用一勺豆瓣醬)。
examples.pinyin: Zhè dào yúxiāng ròusī yào yòng yì sháo dòubànjiàng.
examples.english: This yuxiang shredded pork needs a spoonful of doubanjiang.

examples.chinese: 四川人常用豆瓣酱炒菜(四川人常用豆瓣醬炒菜)。
examples.pinyin: Sìchuān rén cháng yòng dòubànjiàng chǎo cài.
examples.english: People in Sichuan often stir-fry with doubanjiang.

examples.chinese: 我喜欢把豆瓣酱拌进面条里(我喜歡把豆瓣醬拌進麵條裡)。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ xǐhuan bǎ dòubànjiàng bàn jìn miàntiáo lǐ.
examples.english: I like to mix doubanjiang into my noodles.
